user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_daemon_info:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN const union MHD_DaemonInfo *
MHD_get_daemon_info (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                     enum MHD_DaemonInfoType info_type,
                     ...)
{
  if (NULL == daemon)
    return NULL;

  mhd_assert ((0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) || \
              (NULL != daemon->worker_pool) || \
              (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));
  mhd_assert (((0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY)) &&
               (NULL == daemon->worker_pool)) || \
              (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (daemon->tid)));

  switch (info_type)
  {
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_MAC_KEY_SIZE:
    return NULL;   /* no longer supported */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_LISTEN_FD:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd.listen_fd = daemon->listen_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_listen_fd;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_EPOLL_FD:
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd.epoll_fd = daemon->epoll_fd;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_epoll_fd;
#else  /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
    return NULL;
#endif /* ! EPOLL_SUPPORT */
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_CURRENT_CONNECTIONS:
    if (! MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
      MHD_cleanup_connections (daemon);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    else if (daemon->worker_pool)
    {
      unsigned int i;
      /* Collect the connection information stored in the workers. */
      daemon->connections = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < daemon->worker_pool_size; i++)
      {
        /* FIXME: next line is thread-safe only if read is atomic. */
        daemon->connections += daemon->worker_pool[i].connections;
      }
    }
#endif
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections.num_connections
      = daemon->connections;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_num_connections;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_FLAGS:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags.flags = daemon->options;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_flags;
  case MHD_DAEMON_INFO_BIND_PORT:
    daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port.port = daemon->port;
    return &daemon->daemon_info_dummy_port;
  default:
    return NULL;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_get_daemon_info:
#define EPOLL_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Given the provided additional definitions (EPOLL_SUPPORT = 1, MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS = 1), the only compile-time excluded/unreachable fragment inside MHD_get_daemon_info is the #else branch for the EPOLL_SUPPORT conditional. Other parts of the function are either included by the active macros or are runtime-dependent (switch cases selected by info_type, runtime checks such as daemon == NULL, MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_(daemon), daemon->worker_pool, and the mhd_assert checks). The thread-related block controlled by #if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS) is included because MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS is defined, so it is not unreachable. The remaining return statements inside each switch case are normal control flow (they are reached based on info_type at runtime) and the assertion lines are compile-time present but do not themselves constitute unreachable code. Therefore no other fragments were marked as suspicious.
